lines.text: Hey, Ding... is there an apostrophe in "we're"?
As in what?
As in "we're in the shit."
Oh, yes.
Why did you join the Army?
To keep out of trouble.
So your thought if you joined up they'd be no more trouble?
Best thing I ever did. Never been in trouble since.
What the bloody hell do you call this?

[when talking to the camera before leaving for the mission]
Dinger. Ex-Para, Chain smoker. Comment? My God, my country, my Harley Davidson. Not necessarily in that order.

[Narrating]
Of course you're afraid - anyone who says they're not are either lying or need to see a shrink. You want to make the biggest hole possible to hide in - you'd get your spoon out and start digging if that would help. But then the training takes over... you psych yourself up, check all your pouches are closed, your pockets don't open and your magazines are on tight.

[Narrating]
For the next hour we fought a running battle with the jundies
[British military slang for Arab enemy soldiers]
as they pursued us across the plain.

[Narrating]
The Bergens were binned - we couldn't move quickly enough with them. Our belt kits carried what we couldn't do without - water and ammo. We could hear contacts in the distance. Whoever they were firing at, it wasn't us.
[first lines]

For Allied Forces in the Golf the preparation is over. The real battle, only days away. This relentless activity is a reminder that if final-hour diplomacy stumbles, then action against Iraq will be both certain and uncompromising. Saddam Hussein says it will be the mother of all battles. President Bush demanded that conflict must be swift and decisive.
This will not be another Vietnam. This will not be a protracted, drawn-out war.
Every soldier hopes for a major war in his lifetime. This one was mine.

[in custody]
I wasn't afraid. I was depressed.

[when introducing themselves to the camera before they set off]
Baz, ex-para like Dinger only better looking.

[in the background]
Bollocks!
Comment, I will give up smoking next year.
[pauses]
This year, shit!
We fought the raggi's for the best part of the day. We binned our bergens. Couldn't move quick enough with them. We heard contacts far on in the distance. But they weren't shooting at us.
Did you know that Saddam Hussein is an anagram of 'He's a sad nudist?'
Where did the 'M' go?
I swapped it for a 'T'.
You can't do that.
Well I just did.
That's not right.

[speaking in narration, while demonstrating his foreskin]
I pulled as hard as I could, which was difficult, due to the cold.
This is your nuclear, biological, and chemical protection suit, and bibs. Just think of it as a large condom with legs.
If the Iraqis didn't kill us, the weather was going to.
Once again, what is your name?
McNab.
Your rank?
Sargent.
And your unit?
Under the Geneva Convention, I'm afraid I cannot answer that question.

[into his ear]
Fool! We are not in Geneva.

So, Andy, what was your unit doing in this part of the world? Israeli, British, doesn't matter much to me. For now. However, both countries would not send men who know "jack shit" into their enemy's territory.

[answering reporter]
As far as I'm concerned it's over. Saddam Hussein has better know it's over. If Saddam Hussein makes the mistake of starting it again, then he's going to have a lot more trouble than he has on his hands right now.
The psychiatrists turned up to check us for signs of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder. Turned out they were more strung-out than we were.
[last lines]

We're soldiers. It's my profession and I'm proud of it. Nobody said you had to be crap at it. As for the men who tortured us, they had a job to do as well. It's just that some of them enjoyed it a but too much. If I met any of them in the street tomorrow, and thought I could get away with it, I'd slot them.
A patrol of eight went out. Only five returned.
